awd_titl_txt: RUI: Electrophilic Modulation of the Heat Shock Response System
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Rebecca Connor of Dickinson College to investigate how stress affects individual cells in tissues and organs. It is thought that one way cells protect themselves against environmental stresses such as toxins is through a process known as the heat shock response. This project is investigating how certain stress-inducing molecules interact with proteins involved in the heat shock response. It is known that the body's ability to make use of this protective system decreases with age, so the work is also giving deeper insight into how the cellular aging process occurs. This work is having a broader impact on the understanding of basic biological processes that help to maintain good health. Knowledge gained from this work will be useful for a number of fields, including toxicology. The work is having a further broad impact on the training of the next generation of scientists through the many undergraduates at this institution who are participating in the research project.

In this project, studies are being carried out to determine how parthenolide and similar electrophilic molecules chemically affect the cellular heat shock response system (HSR) of cells through covalent modification of the chaperone proteins Hsp70 and Hsp90 and the transcription factor, Hsf1. Peptide enrichment of affinity tagged parthenolide derivatives combined with MALDI-TOF/TOF analysis identifies covalently-adducted amino acids. Mutation of these residues as well as covalent adduction sites previously published in the literature are being used in combination with kinetic binding, protein refolding, co-immunoprecipitation and electrophoretic shift assays to build a complete picture of the effect of modification on heat shock protein (Hsp) function. Both the identification of specific amino acid residues involved in the activation of the heat shock protein response by electrophilic molecules and the quantification of the specific effects on binding affinity, chaperone activity and DNA binding of the Hsps found in the heat shock complex are helping clarify how the heat shock response is controlled. The sensor mechanisms of the heat shock complex are important for the cellular response to environmental toxins and other molecules, as well as cellular senescence.

por.por_cntn:
With this grant, Dr. Rebecca Connor and undergraduates at Dickinson College have studied the effects of chemically reactive or electrophilic compounds such as parthenolide and 4-hydroxynonenal on the heat shock cytoprotective response system in human cells.  Through this project, parthenolide was shown to induce heat shock in human cells and affect the function of the heat shock protein Hsp70. Hsp70 is central to the heat shock stress responsive system and modification of Hsp70 has multiple downstream effects, from the release of co-chaperones to the genetic induction of heat shock proteins.  Using high-resolution mass spectrometry, the specific sites of modification of Hsp70 and Hsp90 were determined. These sites of modification were then potential locations for mutational analysis of Hsp70 and Hsp90 to test how changes to those amino acids affect function. Similar reactive compounds to parthenolide and 4-hydroxynonenal are encountered by cells and arise from both external and internal sources, such as plant extracts or oxidized lipids.  Understanding how the interactions between these molecules and protective cellular systems such as the heat shock system can enable better prediction of response of cancers to electrophilic therapeutics, allergic reactions to plant extracts and oils, and toxicity of electrophilic compounds from environmental sources. This work has also studied the molecular mechanisms causing the heat shock system to respond to certain types of electrophilic molecules.

 

This grant has facilitated not only summer research for 8 undergraduates, but has also allowed the incorporation of an authentic research project in a traditional biochemistry laboratory through material supplies and the purchase of two instruments (Bio-layer Optical Interferometers or BLiTz) for measurement of protein-protein interactions.  Protein-protein interactions are integral to formation of the heat shock complex and are not usually studied in a traditional biochemistry laboratory. Beyond just the project directly related to Hsp70, a one-week lab experiment has been developed where the Blitz is used in conjunction with fluorescence to monitor the expression of a fluorescent protein. This experiment introduces students to two concepts that they encounter in the Hsp70 project: recombinant protein expression and bio-layer interferometry to measure protein binding. This introductory module has been presented in multiple venues to other chemical educators.

 

 Through the biochemical teaching laboratory, more than 115 undergraduates majoring in Chemistry, Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Biology and Neuroscience have participated in biochemistry research related to this project, involving state of the art scientific research equipment. These students have gone on to medical school, dental school, graduate programs, engineering programs and other opportunities according to their interests.  The students who worked on the project during the summers also were able to present their work at American Chemical Society National Meetings in undergraduate and open poster sessions.  This grant has provided equipment, research training, career development through conference attendance, authentic research experiences in classes, networking opportunities, and material supplies for undergraduates at Dickinson College. It is hoped that those students will be ambassadors for science and scientific ways of thinking to their communities, families and friends, even if they do not continue to participate in scientific research in their careers.
